title: Tuesday, 13th March, 2018

Swedish Chef Can you imagine a conversation with your spouse along the lines of "I'm remortgaging the house dear to pay off a porn star"
BE11:13am

Downgrade wise we're only looking at 7% off consensus, but the real bad news here is that things looked to be getting better and now they're not.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Peel Hunt's Charles Hall is entirely done.

BE11:14am

Having promised significant new business wins, the company has now recognised that these will be slower than hoped and that it needs to address under-utilised plants in the US. This under-utilisation is the main driver of the profit warning, although the recent weather in the UK will have impacted Food to Go sales in the short term. We are also throwing in the towel and moving to a hold recommendation. Management credibility is clearly damaged and we do not have confidence re the scale, timing and impact of new business wins to have a positive recommendation. Furthermore H1 profits will be c25% lower, which means that the full-year outcome will be more H2-weighted than normal.

Shinshin @Sos £100 a pack chewing gum tax seems about right
BE11:15am

A reminder that we're here because Greencore lost a £70m contract with Starbucks for -- if I remember correctly -- frozen breakfast sandwiches.

Swedish Chef The movement of frozen breakfast sandwiches and fresh chicken is a underappreciated art
11:15 am
BE11:16am

Management said it could make up the gap with new contracts. Turns out it has had to do a bit more work than expected to land those contracts. The market for frozen breakfast sandwiches desires innovation and forward thinking, apparently.

Soundbuy Salivating here.........
SoS @shinshin Ah well we will see at 12:30. Mind you it does seem these days that all measures are announce, sorry leaked beforehand these days

SupposeToBeWorking... Any thoughts on the university strikes? Kicking off a bit today. Has some odd brexit-vote-like characteristics.
BE11:17am

The shares are trading on a PE of 9.6x to Sep 2018E and EV/EBITDA of 7.3x falling to 8.5x and 6.5x the following year. This may look attractive, but Greencore has a track record of missing expectations. Given that the new business wins depend on third parties, there must still be some concern re timing, scale and integration. If the company does deliver on reduced numbers, the shares should improve on the current level. The dividend (2.6x covered) will be providing some support at a yield of 4.1%.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And Barclays, which is prepared to give a bit more benefit of the doubt.

BE11:17am

We note that Greencore is now trading on a P/company guided FY18 EPS of 9.2x, based on current price of 140p. In our “Overweight” initiation note, we had highlighted several issues with Greencore, namely the problems in its US-legacy and UK-rest business, as well as the quality of its earnings and cash flow. We had suggested that the company should move aggressively to address these issues to create a better long-term trajectory of EPS and cash delivery.

Some of the issues highlighted today in the profit warning suggest that our concerns should have been deeper. We still think that the key UK business (71% of EBIT) and the acquired Peacock business (29% of EBIT) remain in healthy shape. The problems are centered in the US-legacy business where Greencore invested $250mn over years and didn’t make any EBIT. The stock lost more in market capitalization today than the entire amount Greencore invested in its US-legacy business, due to the problems largely centered there. It might have been worthwhile for the management to bite the bullet last year and address the issues head-on in its US legacy business. We hope that the management has now created a path from which the value of its growth businesses – UK ready to go and Peacock – gets more clearly reflected in the stock price. We think management credibility has been negatively impacted post this profit downgrade, and it will likely take several quarters of delivery for investors to focus on the attractive elements of the investment thesis again.

The company gave a fairly good steer on numbers at January trading statement where they guided for revenue "expected to be circa £169 million". Therefore, there are no surprises here on sales. FY17 revenue came in at £170.2m (vs consensus £168.5m), adjusted EBITDA was £58.7m (consensus £57.8m) and net income was slightly ahead of expectations at £45.5m (consensus £43.8m). In the statement management flag an "encouraging start to 2018" and management remain confident that they are "increasingly well positioned to deliver further growth across the business". We do not expect any changes to consensus expectations at this stage given that the weighting of January and February is very small. We remain Overweight and continue to see strong growth opportunity from the premiumisation of mixers, particularly in the United States where Fever-Tree highlight that the focus on "long drink mixability is accelerating".

Therefore, we retain our HOLD stance.

Direct Line has consistently been our preferred UK motor player due to its attractive dividend yield which is underpinned by a conservative balance sheet. We believe Direct Line is now entering a transitory phase where the capital management story is well understood by investors (hence reflected in the current share price), whereas the benefits of positive strategic initiatives may still be a couple of years away from showing tangible benefit. Also keeping in mind short-term headwinds from higher claims inflation in the Home segment, the Nationwide deal running off and pricing uncertainty in the Motor segment due to ‘whiplash reforms’, we downgrade our rating to Hold.

BE11:41am

Reported revenue grew 22.3% y-o-y to £70.1m (ahead of our
£68.4m) aided by strong volume growth, positive price/mix and FX tailwinds. All three divisions saw growth with Polyolefin foams ahead and HPP below our growth assumptions. Gross margins were 36.3%, up 90bps y-o-y. Adjusted operating profit (excluding amortisation of acquired intangibles) grew 20% y-o-y to £9.7m, 5.6% ahead of our £9.5m, as higher Polyolefin profit (+£1.6m better) was partially offset by lower HPP (-£0.5m below) and a greater MuCell loss (£0.5m higher). Adjusted and fully diluted EPS was 17.1p, up 18.6% y-o-y and 12.6% ahead of our 15.2p aided by lower than expected interest costs and tax. The final dividend increased 3.1% y-o-y to 4.02p, ahead of our 3.99p. Net debt was £18.0m, up £5.4m on FY16, and above our £14.1m. This was mainly due to higher than forecast inventory levels within working capital.

BE11:42am

Our increased revenue growth assumptions more than absorb the c.3% FX headwinds in FY18E. The investment made over recent years in HPP is now starting to deliver strong growth at healthy margins. The increasing profits allows the Board to continue to invest in both people and production capacity with the announcement today of an additional $9m to be deployed to bring on line the second US autoclave (HP2) by the end of 2019. This will add another c.20% to total production capacity on top of the 20% added by HP1. The £12m investment in Croydon will also added HPP capacity to help deliver higher volumes, partly to supply the Nike partnership. We upgrade our TP by 20p to 490p to reflect our upgraded FY19E forecasts. With our EPS forecasts providing 18% CAGR (FY17-FY20E), the valuation is fairly reflecting this growth. Hold.

BE11:53am

The fact that Broadcom’s bid for Qualcomm is now DOA is hardly a surprise given the CFIUS investigation. What came as a surprise was the speed with which the White House handed down a presidential order, which cannot be appealed. The decision is based around credible evidence that the deal “threatens to impair the national security of the United States”. Companies are able to challenge CFIUS decisions in court but may not challenge the inter-agency’s national security findings which means that the national security ‘card’ has been played to kill the deal. Washington’s concern is likely less about Broadcom being a Singapore-domiciled company (after all it has a corporate headquarters in California) or even the fact that over 50% of revenues are derived from China (and 65% of Qualcomm revenues are from customers in China, including Hong Kong). It is probably more about Broadcom’s historical MO of budget cutting that could hand the 5G initiative to Huawei at the expense of Qualcomm. Qualcomm spent $5.5B on R&D in FY2017, which amounts to 25% of revenues. Would this be considered inefficient under a Broadcom ownership structure given that Qualcomm’s revenues declined 5% YoY in 2017. Huawei have been ramping their own R&D efforts and grew R&D 21% YoY in 2016 (last FY accounts available) to reach $11.5B, double Qualcomm’s level.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

The importance of IP, particularly around 5G IP, is at the heart of the issue. As can be seen from the infographic below (LexInnova Study), Qualcomm together with equipment suppliers Nokia and Ericsson are in the top five of the 5G radio front-end technology patent holders. However, the rise of the significant presence of Chinese entities indicates that they may have a similar 5G deployment timeline to the USA. A range of recent announcements show the strength of Huawei in 5G. Network slicing is a key technology within 5G. It enables applications, device and syustems connected to a network to optimize their own requirements which can protect performance and offer significant performance and reliability, is a key characteristic of 5G Networks. Huawei has significant solutions in Network slicing, as seen in a report detailing the operation of smart electricity grid infrastructure in January this year.

BE11:54am

FDI (Foreign Direct Investment) between China and the US has been a one-way street since the late 1970s which has seen China essentially rise to become the world’s factory. Then, with the emergence of China as the world’s second-largest economy, the trend reversed with Chinese investment into the US surpassing that from the US to China since 2014. Chinese FDI in the US peaked in 2016, as did total outbound investment of $170B, and has shrunk significantly since. This is not only due to the increased scrutiny of Chinese investment by CFIUS (Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States) but also due to change in the Chinese government’s own adjustment in regulating FDI. The famed $900B belt and road infrastructure initiative led to a number of SOEs taking on risky financial projects and the government declared that “some investments do not meet our industrial policy requirements for outward investment…they are not of great benefit to China”, Zhou Xiaochuan, China central bank governor. It could be argued that both China and the U.S. are taking routes that are more protectionist in nature and further signs of the end of the globalisation movement.

BE11:54am

At the end of this particular soap-opera one thing is clear. Companies will need to resist foreign capital and strategic opportunities for global expansion will be curtailed. Curb your enthusiasm.
